When peas are sown IN antumn or early
in spring they are liable to be eaten by mice,
To prevent this, an English writer recon-
mends soaking the peas for day or two in
train oil, before YOU SOW them, which Che
says) will encourage their vegetation and
render them so obnoxious to mice that they
will not eat them. 1t is recommended i'll
all those sorts which grow high, to have only
l row in place, and then leave a bed 10 or
10 feet wide for onions carrots, or any crops
which do not grow tall. The advantages
are that the peas will not be drawn up much
will be stronger-will flower mar the
ground--and IN wet weather can be more
easily gathered without wetting yourself
s'But (says awriterin the Repertory of Arts,)
instead Of sowing peas in straight rows if
you will form the ground into circles of three
feet diameter with space of two feet be-
cween each circle, in row thirty feet long,
you will have six circles of peas, each nine
feet.-in all ffty-four feet ofpeas, instead of
thirty Cne On the same extent ct ground.


"Ifyou want mere than one row OF circles,
leave bed of 10 or IL feet before you begin
another.


''For the very tall sorts, four feet circles
will afford more room for the roots to grow in
and care must be taken, by applying some
slender twiss to prevent the circles from
joining each other"


DIR. Anderson says that lime is the best
manure for land intended to be sown with
peas.


I.oudon. in giving directions for the field
culture Of tins vegetable, says, "the quantity
of seed must be different in different cases
and circumstances. and according To the time
and manner in which the seed is put into
the ground; but in general it may be from
and half to three bushels, the earliest sow
ings have the largest proportion of seed
The most common mode of sowing peas i
broad cast; but the advantages of the ROY
culture in crop so early committed to tn,
soil must be obvious The best farmer
therefore always SOW peas either after tn
plough, the seed being deposited commonl
in every second or third furrow, or it tn
land is in pulverized state, by DRAWN
drills with machine or BY ribbing.

BOAT FOUND.

A communication, IN the last New Eng
,ond E.rmer from a gentleman at Glouces-
.er gives an account Of successful expert
,nent made 10 preserve seed corn, from the
ravapes Of the wire worm and birds by soak
inc & in copperas water before planting,
which completely succeeded. He says


"The field which ! planted, the last year,
was more than half destroyed by worms and
birds. the last time it was planted about
years before, principally by the cut worms
and as many of them were discovered when
ploughing, expected nothing but should
be served the same; but much to my aston
ishment, ] had scarcely hill or even a
spire destroyed, which impute principally
to the copperas.


"The plan which pursued was as fol-
lows: / used about one and an halt pounds
of copperas in three pecks OF corn. ! made
the water warm, and soaked the corn full
as hours before planting, putting IN corn and
copperas as we Used i out.


CUTTING CIONS FOR GRATING


In cutting cions for grating, the follow
ing directions from Forsyth may prove use
ful. Select shoots of the former year; for
where they are older they never succeed
we'll. "Always take them from healthy
fruitful trees; for, if the trees from which
they are taken be sickly, the gratis very Of
ten partake so much Of the distemper as
rarely to get the better of it, at least tor
some years; and when they are taken from
youne luxuriant trees, whose vessels are
generally large, they will continue to pro-
duce luxuriant shoots, but are seldom SO
productive as those which are taken from
fruitful trees whose shoots are more compact
and the joints closer together, at least 1t wli
be great number of years before the lux
uriant gratis begin to produce fruit, even i
managed with the greatest skill. lol
should prefer those gratis which are takeT
from the lateral or horizontal branches, Z
those from the strong perpendicular shoots
for the reasons before given


"These gratis, or cons, should be cut OF
from the trees before their buds begin Il
swell, which is generally three weeks or {
month before the season for grating there
fore, when they are cut off they should b'
laid in the ground with the cut downwards
burrying them half their length, and cover
ing their tops with dry litter, to preven
their dying; if small Joint of the forme
years wood be cut off with the con, it viii
preserve it the better, and when they ar
grated, this may be cut off; for at the sam
time the cions must be cut oil to prope
length before they are inserted in the stock
but. till then, the shoots should remain c
their full length, as they were taken tror
the tree, which will better preserve ther
from shrinking: if these cions are to be ca,
ried to considerable distance, it Will b
proper to put their ends into lump of ella,
and to wrap them up in moss, which wi
preserve them fresh for month, or longe
but these should be cut off from the tree
earlier than those which are to be giraffe
near the,place where the trees are growing,

full articles.headline: Young Ladies' Boarding School,
full articles.article:
Under the superintendent and instruction y,
WILLIAM SHERER, assisted by accomplished
female teachers.


The course of instruction pursued at this SEM
inary comprises all the useful, and most OF t,'e
ornamental branches o. female education. Inc
daily exercises are Orthography, Reading Writ-
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar, hhetoric'
Geography and History, ancient ana nio'icri,
with constant reference to the best maps ana
charts; Construction OF maps; use OF inc nioUcs'
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemlstryi Eieinehts Vi Mo'"'
Science.


JJpekiy Ercrcises.--Biblical Rcchatlons; Evi-
denccs Of Christianity; Letter Writing, and 9th
or species of Compositions; Recaptulations


Terms. board and tuition, in any OF the tore, !,
going branches, s32, so per quarter; or, II paiu
in advance, $50 Music, including the use Oh
piano, s12 French, by one of the best masters
Sc pcr quarter Moderate extra charges for
Drawing and other ornamental branches


The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian. Particular attention is pald not
only to the manners of the young ladies'. Du' 10
their moral and religious instruction. iGy are
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dians approve Exercise and recreation, being
essential to the preservation OF health and OF
mental energy. occupy the intervals OF time not
devoted to study. The institution, in all its de-
partments, is conducted in MANNER winch 1t
is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF It's
patrons. ~, -,

full articles.headline:
A pI1pLIC EXHIBITION

OF Jpl!lam Larkh's .Msqo System othayins


Old Debts.
full articles.article:
Old Debts.


Master Billy. are YOU not ashamed to call me 4
quandan quack, as the public sees that my sal
taburas pills had a more eilectual and poweriui
operation on your system than all the medicihe
YOU have taken these five years past; ior my sal
taburas pills, caused you TO quit the field OF &C
ton in a short and dirty hurry, without second
appeal to the public or an apology for the con
temptuous treatment you have given the puohc
BY your endeavoring to impose false assertion,
which YOU had TO swallow as dog docs his vom-
it. We had taken the shorte stand plainest way
to prove that you was imposing on the public
with the most bare.faced falsehood, which we
put stop to, when We challenged you to call on
any three, four, or more Of the respectable men
in this borough, and appoint your time, and we
would meet you face TO face, and it you could
produce one receipt or settlement from the trtls-
tees of st. Peters Chrch, for any sum OF mo-
ncy even for one dollar, from the commencement
of the drawing of the Lottery until this day, we
would acknowledge your assertion tob true
We gave YOU forty light hours TO come forward.
you did not tappear--nether could you in forty
eight years with the documents demanded, so
that you prove vourtclf to be l--r, for Offering
such false assertions to the public. In your state
ment Of the sale Of the two first classes OF the
lottery there is ialsehood q school boy may
'
state you sold ,he two frs, classes Of thc lottery
for $500 each, which SUNS made but Sl000 and
you tell the public you paid the church out of
the proceeds Of these two classes the sum OF
s1605: here Billy you prove yourself false again
Billy you hold the proceeds of the lottery five
years, and finding your pOstatums cannot be
any longer imposed on the public, nor your
pseudo account without day date, be any long
er suffered to procrastnatc your plo'tarlous i'm
passions, rs respects your rhonest actions respect
ing the lottery in your farewell to the trustees
and your respected friend the quandam quack.
oh; we cont intend to take our leave of you,
dear Billy, as We have found your bond which
YOU passed to Governor Collins, which binds yo,
in the penalty often thousand dollars to discharge
the trust the church confded in you. 1t ispos
sble Billy as you now arc in the possession o
| this fact that if it WAS more convenient to YOU
| YOU would prefer the trustees and the quandan
were in Guinea. What did you do with the fou


wrts You had marked out against the four trus
tees for scandalzing your character, by inform


ing the public that you held both pew rent, sub
scription and lottery money from the church,


oh, Billy, The public n large sees you delineat
cd in your real colours You sWorc that thu
four trustees YOU took out wrts against was TO


leaving the state, or something TO that effect
TO prevent them ofsal ing any thing more abon
I
say you viii not settle with the unprincipict
trti itccs--you would prefer settling with some o
the backwoodsmci, whom YOU could tell tut
tale to, and wash it down with gallon Of whis


key. Billy the trustees will ncverask a settle


ment from yon again, the Law must settle il now
Billy, your friend, the quantam, sends his bes


respects 70 yoa in a cabbage leaf, 10 inform yol


that the people who knew you where YOU com


from say that you were man in public business


and thst your htbitaton was an exalted one


what the people in England calls Paddy's garle


or the fiist story below the pavement; an


that you WASH inferior in your business TO an
man in Dubn to give a copel polish 10 a pair {


boots or shoes, and the people that You are Gel
tain knew you when you come 10 tl,is county
and know you still, say when you come here 20
: had the respectable appearance ofa Spittle-iicl
wcavcr--that Your dut!ds was tackled on yo
with more pins than buttons Billy, from you
respectable standing in society, we are not t


wonder at your barking like mastilf dog at an


person who should attempt 20 bring you to ju


tice, but your barking is useless. | would nc
give you up 10 prohigacy, my dear Billy, for
bunch Of matches. Your devoted friend,


PURCELL
N. Il. Patrick Higgins has document
= yours, which fully proves what you arc,


l March IL, 1927. 26--4tp.

full articles.headline: PEAS.
full articles.article:
When peas are sown IN antumn or early
in spring they are liable to be eaten by mice,
To prevent this, an English writer recon-
mends soaking the peas for day or two in
train oil, before YOU SOW them, which Che
says) will encourage their vegetation and
render them so obnoxious to mice that they
will not eat them. 1t is recommended i'll
all those sorts which grow high, to have only
l row in place, and then leave a bed 10 or
10 feet wide for onions carrots, or any crops
which do not grow tall. The advantages
are that the peas will not be drawn up much
will be stronger-will flower mar the
ground--and IN wet weather can be more
easily gathered without wetting yourself
s'But (says awriterin the Repertory of Arts,)
instead Of sowing peas in straight rows if
you will form the ground into circles of three
feet diameter with space of two feet be-
cween each circle, in row thirty feet long,
you will have six circles of peas, each nine
feet.-in all ffty-four feet ofpeas, instead of
thirty Cne On the same extent ct ground.


"Ifyou want mere than one row OF circles,
leave bed of 10 or IL feet before you begin
another.


''For the very tall sorts, four feet circles
will afford more room for the roots to grow in
and care must be taken, by applying some
slender twiss to prevent the circles from
joining each other"


DIR. Anderson says that lime is the best
manure for land intended to be sown with
peas.


I.oudon. in giving directions for the field
culture Of tins vegetable, says, "the quantity
of seed must be different in different cases
and circumstances. and according To the time
and manner in which the seed is put into
the ground; but in general it may be from
and half to three bushels, the earliest sow
ings have the largest proportion of seed
The most common mode of sowing peas i
broad cast; but the advantages of the ROY
culture in crop so early committed to tn,
soil must be obvious The best farmer
therefore always SOW peas either after tn
plough, the seed being deposited commonl
in every second or third furrow, or it tn
land is in pulverized state, by DRAWN
drills with machine or BY ribbing.

full articles.headline: ADVERTISEMENT.
full articles.article:
10 |He E0H1r J NE bHWWS1oHlaH'


In your last Number, an additional iogo
and scurrious publication has appeared a
ganst me from the famous Would-be Irus-
tees OF St. Peters Church. backed by the
certificate OF Patrick Higgins. and the after
piece of the notorious Quack Doctor, of Oh
hoSSum memory. That shameful production,
fraught with the most giaring falsehoods, is
degrading, and unworthy the character Of
any Trustees, and Which, as member,
much regret.


have turned those "Trustees" over to
the legal authority WHO have no doubt will
duly appreciate their wants, and do them
that Justice their infamous deeds deserve.


My statement. by way of reply, in your
former paper, is Substantially correct; and
have been, and am readyand willing to settle
on just and equitable terms with the church,
with any men selected who are not devoid Of
principle, but ] never can condcsccnd to
men so destitute Of every principle that cha
racterizes the individuals who have so wan
tonly assaicd my character


| With respect to the certificate of Patrick,
! it is a bundle of absurdities worthy the au-
thor He says he has known me for TWEEN
| ty-hve wears, (it is true, and the only truth
he has asscrted,): he has known me, and |
have we'll known him to my sorrow. He can
advert to the time and well remember, who
first started him in Thoroughfare Neck, and
who it was that WAS the loserthereby byhisfr-
regular spGys, and who afterwards helped
him back to Wilmington, and aided him when


without friends, or money to pay his debts or


subsst upon, and from motives of charity
gave him employ when not worth penny
Ask and reflect, does il argue we'll for Pat


rick to sting the hand Of his 6encfaCtor, sad
der like,' that hand which nourished and
sustained him!


Next, in order, would notice the knigh


of the Bolus whose stupidity is only equallet


by his impudence in bringing into view thu


name of my friend Of the city Of Lancaster


whom he had induced to suppose THAT h'
was man OF reputation" and had decoyet


to his residence; which, when by me dis
t. cerned, for the safety Of his character ai'
: person called for, considering him unsaf
r in the company of such "reht,ie."
!, now take leave of the "Trustees OF 81
o Peters Church." patrick" and his guam
n dam friend, the Quack, intending or no fu
N ture occasion to notice their nefagioas pro
/ ductions.


N WM. LARKtN.


Wilmington, March z, ls27.-25--4t.

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

PRESERVATION OF SEED CORN.
full articles.article:
A communication, IN the last New Eng
,ond E.rmer from a gentleman at Glouces-
.er gives an account Of successful expert
,nent made 10 preserve seed corn, from the
ravapes Of the wire worm and birds by soak
inc & in copperas water before planting,
which completely succeeded. He says


"The field which ! planted, the last year,
was more than half destroyed by worms and
birds. the last time it was planted about
years before, principally by the cut worms
and as many of them were discovered when
ploughing, expected nothing but should
be served the same; but much to my aston
ishment, ] had scarcely hill or even a
spire destroyed, which impute principally
to the copperas.


"The plan which pursued was as fol-
lows: / used about one and an halt pounds
of copperas in three pecks OF corn. ! made
the water warm, and soaked the corn full
as hours before planting, putting IN corn and
copperas as we Used i out.


CUTTING CIONS FOR GRATING


In cutting cions for grating, the follow
ing directions from Forsyth may prove use
ful. Select shoots of the former year; for
where they are older they never succeed
we'll. "Always take them from healthy
fruitful trees; for, if the trees from which
they are taken be sickly, the gratis very Of
ten partake so much Of the distemper as
rarely to get the better of it, at least tor
some years; and when they are taken from
youne luxuriant trees, whose vessels are
generally large, they will continue to pro-
duce luxuriant shoots, but are seldom SO
productive as those which are taken from
fruitful trees whose shoots are more compact
and the joints closer together, at least 1t wli
be great number of years before the lux
uriant gratis begin to produce fruit, even i
managed with the greatest skill. lol
should prefer those gratis which are takeT
from the lateral or horizontal branches, Z
those from the strong perpendicular shoots
for the reasons before given


"These gratis, or cons, should be cut OF
from the trees before their buds begin Il
swell, which is generally three weeks or {
month before the season for grating there
fore, when they are cut off they should b'
laid in the ground with the cut downwards
burrying them half their length, and cover
ing their tops with dry litter, to preven
their dying; if small Joint of the forme
years wood be cut off with the con, it viii
preserve it the better, and when they ar
grated, this may be cut off; for at the sam
time the cions must be cut oil to prope
length before they are inserted in the stock
but. till then, the shoots should remain c
their full length, as they were taken tror
the tree, which will better preserve ther
from shrinking: if these cions are to be ca,
ried to considerable distance, it Will b
proper to put their ends into lump of ella,
and to wrap them up in moss, which wi
preserve them fresh for month, or longe
but these should be cut off from the tree
